G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Modification of custody orders is governed by G.L. c. 208, § 28, which allows for modification when a material change in circumstances has occurred, and the modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209B.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, as the initial custody judgment was issued by this Court, and Massachusetts is the home state of the child under the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act, G.L. c. 209B.

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 736 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Massachusetts courts require that the primary consideration in custody modifications is the best interests of the child.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in both initial custody determinations and later modifications, the guiding principle has always been the best interests of the children. It ties this directly to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and cites prior Massachusetts cases for that same rule, showing that Massachusetts courts treat the child’s best interests as the primary consideration in custody modifications. The court then applies that best-interests standard to evaluate the split-custody order at issue.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28… enables a Probate Court judge… to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’… When determining child custody awards in general, or modifications of custody awards based on changed circumstances, the guiding principle always has been the best interests of the children. Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404 (1981).”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 845 (200.proposition: Massachusetts courts require that the primary consideration in custody modifications is the best interests of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 845 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly reaffirms that custody determinations in Massachusetts are governed by the "best interests of the child" standard and describes it as the paramount concern. While this case is not itself a modification proceeding under § 20, the court discusses the best-interests standard as the controlling principle for custody awards and emphasizes that all relevant factors must be weighed in light of the child’s best interests. Thus it supports the general proposition that Massachusetts courts require the child’s best interests to be the primary consideration in custody (including modification) decisions.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 845 (200.relevant_excerpt: In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is "best for the child" is firmly rooted in American history... The "best interests" standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865... It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002) (best interests standard "has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation"); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) ("best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern").

Care and Protection of Georgette, 54 Mas.proposition: A court may modify custody specifically where issues of schooling, attendance, and academic welfare arise as material changes.
Care and Protection of Georgette, 54 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion is a care and protection / termination of parental rights decision focused on parental unfitness, ineffective assistance, and Rule 60(b)(6) relief. It does not discuss modification of custody based on schooling, attendance, or academic welfare as material changes, nor does it set out any rule about altering custody orders in that context. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Care and Protection of Georgette, 54 Mas.relevant_excerpt: The opinion primarily concerns the father’s unfitness and the denial of a Rule 60(b)(6) motion; there is no discussion of custody modification grounded in schooling, attendance, or academic performance as material changes. The court’s analysis instead focuses on the father’s abuse, neglect, alcoholism, and the applicable standards for relief from judgment and ineffective assistance of counsel.

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 497 (2012.proposition: Courts have found that failure to cooperate in shared legal custody arrangements undermines the child’s best interests.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 497 (2012.support_reasoning: The court’s best-interests analysis expressly considers a parent’s efforts to alienate the child from the other legal parent as a negative factor in custody. It affirms the trial judge’s finding that the parent who undermined the child’s relationship with the other parent caused harm and that it was in the child’s best interest to be in the custody of the parent who would support involvement of both parents. This directly supports the proposition that failure to cooperate in shared legal custody arrangements undermines the child’s best interests.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 497 (2012.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that disrupting the attachment a child has to a parent and behaving in ways designed to alienate a child from that parent causes harm that can be long term, and if sole physical custody must be awarded because of geographic distance between parents, ‘it is in the best interests of a child to be in the sole custody of the parent who can support the involvement of both parents rather than with the parent who alienates the child from the other parent.’ … see Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 244 (2000) (custody to parent willing to respect other parent’s role in child’s life).”}

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 405 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: Courts have found that failure to cooperate in shared legal custody arrangements undermines the child’s best interests.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses the viability of joint/shared custody and ties it to the parents’ ability to cooperate and jointly make decisions. The court explicitly states that joint custody requires mutual agreement and a willingness and ability to work together, and concludes that in this case joint custody “would be entirely inappropriate and injurious to the children” and “an invitation to continued warfare and conflict.” This aligns with the proposition that failure or inability to cooperate in a shared legal custody arrangement undermines the child’s best interests.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “[W]e agree with the trial judge’s observation that in order for joint custody or shared responsibility to work, both parents must be able mutually ‘to agree on the basic issues in child rearing and want to cooperate in making decisions for [their] children.’ … ‘Although complete agreement between parents to implement joint custody may not be necessary,’ in order to be effective ‘joint custody requires two capable parents with some degree of respect for one another’s abilities as parents, together with a willingness and ability to work together to reach results on major decisions….’ … The judge concluded that ‘joint custody or shared responsibility is an invitation to continued warfare and conflict.’”}

K.J. v. M.A., 100 Mass. App. Ct. 216, 22.proposition: School attendance and academic progress are recognized as key components of a child's best interests.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 597 (1.proposition: School attendance and academic progress are recognized as key components of a child's best interests.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 597 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion’s central focus is domestic violence and best interests, but the court does note as part of the best‑interests analysis that the child is “doing well at school” and that the father is “concerned about his education” and meets regularly with teachers. These statements treat school performance and parental involvement in schooling as relevant factors in evaluating the custody arrangement, which fits the proposition that school attendance and academic progress are key components of a child’s best interests, though this is not the primary legal principle of the case.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 597 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that Vaughn ‘is doing well at school. His guidance counsellor is hopeful he will continue to shine in school as he did during his last marking period.’ … The judge was also moved by the fact that the boy appeared to be doing very well in his school work and that the father takes a great interest in his activities, meeting regularly with the boy’s teachers.”

Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 233 (19.proposition: Defendant’s unilateral withholding of critical educational opportunities violates the principles of cooperative parenting.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 233 (19.support_reasoning: The case concerns religious instruction by a noncustodial parent and standards for restricting visitation based on alleged harm to the child. It does not address a parent’s unilateral withholding of educational opportunities, nor does it articulate any general doctrine of ‘cooperative parenting’ in that sense. The holding actually disfavors limiting a parent’s religious activities absent proof of substantial harm, which cuts against using it as authority for the claimed proposition.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 233 (19.relevant_excerpt: “However, harm to the child from conflicting religious instructions or practices, which would justify such a limitation, should not be simply assumed or surmised; it must be demonstrated in detail… The decisions hold such an infirmity to be fatal to an action seeking to limit materially or to cancel visitation rights… Thus there is clear error, for lack of foundation in the record, in the judge’s findings of a ‘deleterious effect’ on the children and an ‘undermining’ of the custodial relationship by reason of the father’s religious instruction or practice.”

Katzman v. Healy, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 589,.raw_text: Katzman v. Healy, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 589, 597-598 (2010)
Katzman v. Healy, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 589,.proposition: A parenting plan that impairs a child’s education constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances justifying modification.
Katzman v. Healy, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 589,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses when a change in parenting time/custody requires a prior finding of a material and substantial change in circumstances under G.L. c. 208, § 28, but it does not address a parenting plan’s impact on a child’s education or treat educational impairment as the requisite change. The court reverses because the judge modified custody without *any* findings of material and substantial change, not because of educational disruption. There is no analysis linking educational impairment to the standard for modification in this case.
Katzman v. Healy, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 589,.relevant_excerpt: “As provided by G. L. c. 208, § 28, … ‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ … To the extent the judge wanted to extend joint physical custody to the father, findings reflecting substantial and material changed circumstances supported by the evidence were required. … No such findings were made here, and therefore so much of the amended modification judgment as increases parenting time for the father and decreases parenting time for the mother is reversed.”
